history.content: IMO, with sufficient probability + linear algebra background, yes. However, you'll want to learn Python for completing the coding questions on the homeworks.

children.subject: Know someone who got an -A from barely doing any code.
Sorry to randomly hijack this, but I was planning on taking 189 next fall semester. Would you heavily recommend trying to take 120 before that?

You've got an outstanding mathematics background. As long as you know some very basic coding and very basic statistics, you're good.

On a semi-related note, I believe Math 118 is one of the best courses for math/physics students to take before 189 (same can be said about EE120).

As you may have found yourself, it provides a framework for understanding the applications of decomposing functions in different ways - CS189 heavily uses intuition like this. At least when I took 189 with sahai, basically every single problem set, discussion, or lecture had topics that Math 118 made easier for me to understand mathematically as well as intuitively. 

As you've taken 118, I imagine you'd have no problem with most variants of 189.

history.content:
Hi, sophomore physics and applied math major here. I haven't taken any other CS classes, but I have a pretty strong math background (I've done Math 104, 110, 113, 118, 202A, 224A).

Would CS 189 be doable for me?
history.subject: Is CS 189 doable without a background in CS?
